Column Comment.0: BUSINESS ASSOCIATE: Unique identifier for a business associate, such as aperson, company, regulatory agency, government or consortium.
Column Comment.1: PAYMENT INSTRUCTION ID: unique identifier for the payment instructions.
Column Comment.2: ABA NUMBER: Number that identifies a bank for automated transfer of funds.
Column Comment.3: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether this row of data is currently eitheractive / valid (Y) or inactive / invalid (N).
Column Comment.4: ADDRESS OBSERVATION NUMBER: A number used to uniquely identifying anaddress for a Business Associate.
Column Comment.5: BANK ADDRESS SOURCE: part of the foreign key from the BA ADDRESS of thebank referenced.
Column Comment.6: BUSINESS ASSOCIATE: Unique identifier for a business associate, such as aperson, company, regulatory agency, government or consortium.
Column Comment.7: BANK FEE: Banks fees charged for this type of payment. Fees may vary for differentcustomers and for different transaction types.
Column Comment.8: CURRENCY CONVERSION RATE: the rate applied to convert the currency from itsoriginal monetary UOM to the stored UOM. This value is valid for this row in this tableonly. When this value is multiplied by the STORED currency value, the original valueof the transaction in the original currency is obtained.
Column Comment.9: CURRENCY ORIGINAL UNITS OF MEASURE: the currency in which the funds wereinitially received. When the Stored currency is multiplied by the CURRENCYCONVERSION, the value of the transaction in the original currency is obtained.
Column Comment.10: DEPOSITORY NUM: Bank account number of payee depository
Column Comment.11: EFFECTIVE DATE: the date on which this row of data first came into effect from abusiness perspective.
Column Comment.12: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row was no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.13: INVALID DATE: The date on which this payment instruction was determined to beinvalid. Could happen when a card expires and no longer works. This may happenafter the payment instruction is actually invalid, as discovery can happen later.
Column Comment.14: R PAYMENT METHOD: The method to be used, such as direct deposit, cash, check.
Column Comment.15: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.16: REMARK: Narrative remarks about this row of data.
Column Comment.17: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.18: SUSPEND PAYMENT IND: Suspension indicator used if payments to this accountare to be suspended for any reason (receivership etc) usually an internal account isset up to collect payments until a direction to resume payments is received.
Column Comment.19: SUSPEND PAYMENT REASON: the reason the obligation payment was suspended,such as bankruptcy etc.
Column Comment.20: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.21: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.22: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.23: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.24: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.25: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.26: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
